summary: E.O. Wilson is a biologist and winner of the 2007 Ted Prize. Wilson: "If we were to wipe out insects alone, just that group alone on this planet, which we are trying hard to do, the rest of life and humanity with it"
"I was enchanted by the natural beauty of that region and the almost tropical exuberance of the plants and animals that grow there," he says. "I never considered anything else in my entire life"
We live on a mostly unexplored planet. The great majority of organisms on Earth remain unknown to science. Consider the fungi, including mushrooms, rust, moles, and many disease-causing organisms

We are living on a planet with a lot of activities with reference to the living environment done by faith and guests alone. Our lives depend upon these creatures. So the question is, what are they all doing? But the fact is, we don't know

Some serious biologists and I count myself among them have begun to wonder that among the enormous and still unknown diversity of microorganisms, one might find aliens among them. We will destroy these ecosystems and the species, composing them at the peril of our own existence

The human juggernaut is permanently eroding earth, ancient biosphere, says author. "HIPPO, the animal HIPPO. H is for habitat destruction, including climate change forced by greenhouse gases" "I is for the invasive species like the ants, the fire ants,

The HIPPO juggernaut we have created, if unabated, is destined to reduce half of earth still surviving animal and plant species to extinction or critical endangerment by the end of the century. The loss will inflict a heavy price in wealth, security, and yes, spirituality for all

We need to have the biosphere properly explored so that we can understand and manage it. We need to settle down before we wreck the planet and we need that knowledge. This should be a big science project equivalent to the Human Genome Project
EO Wilson's TED Talk was recorded at the TED conference in Monterey, California, March 2007. The talk was produced by WNYC New York Public Radio for TED
